body_html:
PoolAllocator is probably not the source of the memory leak. There were a few issues with py_func fixed since then, and one of those might have made your leak go away.
…
On Sat, Oct 13, 2018 at 2:02 AM Niels Ole Salscheider < ***@***.***> wrote: I can't reproduce the problem with the current nightly build. However, the code in PoolAllocator was not touched and still has the problems I described. So I assume that either another allocator is used by default now or that the allocation pattern with my test case changed. — You are receiving this because you were assigned. -- - Alex

body:
PoolAllocator is probably not the source of the memory leak. There were a
few issues with py_func fixed since then, and one of those might have made
your leak go away.

On Sat, Oct 13, 2018 at 2:02 AM Niels Ole Salscheider <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I can't reproduce the problem with the current nightly build. However, the
> code in PoolAllocator was not touched and still has the problems I
> described. So I assume that either another allocator is used by default now
> or that the allocation pattern with my test case changed.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were assigned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/21410#issuecomment-429523800>,
> or mute the thread

> .
